question_1.question: What is the prerequisite for configuring object level permissions in TimeXtender according to the text?

options.option_a: Creating a Database Role in the data area
options.option_c: Assigning a user to a database role

question_1.explanation: Creating a Database Role in the data area is mentioned as a prerequisite for configuring object level permissions in TimeXtender.

question_2.question: Which of the following permission settings is NOT one of the three possible settings for object level security in TimeXtender?
question_2.explanation: The text specifies three permission settings: Not set, Grant, and Deny. Read-only is not mentioned as one of the options.

question_3.question: What happens if a user is a member of a database role that is granted access to an object, but also a member of another role that is denied access?

options.option_a: The user will have access to the object
options.option_b: The user will not have access to the object
options.option_c: The user's access level will be determined by the object's settings
options.option_d: The user will have read-only access to the object

question_3.explanation: According to the text, if a user is a member of a database role that is granted access but also a member of another role that is denied access, the user will not have access to the object.

question_4.question: In TimeXtender, what does the permission icon that is split down the middle indicate?

options.option_a: The object is accessible to all users
options.option_b: The object has row level permissions set
options.option_c: The object has mixed permission settings
options.option_d: The object is in a locked state

question_4.explanation: The text explains that a permission icon for tables that is split down the middle indicates mixed permission settings.
